title: I'm looking for a Serif font with big, strong, prominent punctuation
content:
I'd like to find a font like the one from the book [Eats, Shoots & Leaves](http://web.archive.org/web/20120703011637/http:/books.google.com/books?id=c3ETv37GqfcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=eats,+shoots+%26+leaves&ei=HfH9SIiBNpCoMoDG6KUD#PPR11,M1).

Aldus Manutius the Younger said that the main purpose of punctuation is the clarification of syntax, but I think really strong punctuation can help make reading more musical and playful.

Any ideas? Know what the exact font Truss uses Eats, Shoots & Leaves?
author: blackboxme

The typeface is Quadraat.
Adobe Caslon has pretty strong punctuation. The original Caslon has even darker commas; Founders Caslon will give you that, though you also get an antique look.

some folks say the periods in Clifford are too strong. I don't.

powers

_Know what the exact font Truss uses Eats, Shoots & Leaves?_

FF Quadraat. The wide-looking g is a giveaway :)

edit: oh, sorry, Nick already said that ;)

The irony of FF Quadraat in <cite>Eats, Shoots & Leaves</cite>, at least from my perspective, is that there is no kerning between quotation marks and periods or commas. So the many sentences with phrases enclosed in quotation marks with periods or commas outside have all these huge, unsightly, gaping holes with pitiful little points floating in them.

It's not quite as glaring when the points are contained within quotes, but kerning is still absent.

On second thought, maybe that's why you perceive the punctuation as prominent.

Mildly enjoyed the book, but never got over the irritation of this lack of kerning.

-- K.
Thanks for the info, this issue has bugged me ever since I finished reading E,S&L.

OK, if we're picking on the typography, what's with the faux small caps?!  
And lack of fi and fl ligatures.  
Oh the irony.
